definition: lit. billy goat's horns caught in the fence (idiom from Book of Changes 易經|易经); impossible to advance or to retreat/without any way out of a dilemma/trapped/in an impossible situation
billy goat/ram
surname Yang
sheep/goat/CL:頭|头[tou2],隻|只[zhi1]
to touch/to make contact with sth/to stir up sb's emotions
fence/hedge/screen/barrier/vassal state/Taiwan pr. [fan2]
lit. like stepping on a tiger's tail or spring ice (idiom)/fig. extremely dangerous situation
Mr Zhu Yun breaks the railing (idiom); to challenge and admonish boldly
one-sided words/prejudice/flattery
person narrow-minded and shortsighted
classical final particle, similar to modern 了[le5]
to advance or retreat, each has its rules (idiom from Zhuangzi); many translations are possible
to be tolerant/to be forgiving/to conceal/to cover
to speak/to say
barefooted and barebreasted
see 驚弓之鳥|惊弓之鸟[jing1 gong1 zhi1 niao3]
lit. fight tigers with one's bare hands and wade across raging rivers (idiom)/fig. to display foolhardy courage
that's why it is called...
the solid and broken lines of the eight trigrams 八卦[ba1 gua4], e.g. ☶
too late for regrets (idiom); It is useless to repent after the event.
hastily/rashly/suddenly
to wait for the opportunity
